Title: Good entry-level DSLR
Cons:
Hot spots/stuck pixels at high ISOs, poor AI-Servo auto-focusing, takes slightly blurry pictures with super-telephoto lenses, inaccurate auto-focus with Canon's long lenses, dark viewfinder, poor battery life and slow shutter speed in low light.  If the ISO is over 400 image quality will start to degrade.

The lack of auto-focus assist points make taking pictures of birds in flight very difficult.  Auto-focus with Canon 'L' lenses is not spot on and require manual focusing for tack-sharp pictures.

My biggest gripe is the full auto 'point and shoot' mode disables almost all the menu options in the camera.
Pros:
The camera has most of the features found in Canons more advanced models with a bright 3" LCD on the back.  While it can do a lot at ISO 100 the weaknesses are hard to spot unless you have used it for six months.

With the Canon EF 100-400L this camera is good enough to photograph wildlife.  Wide angle lenses will work but don't fill the viewfinder well.

The auto-focus works for short distances and manual focusing in live-view makes tack-sharp pictures with a remote trigger.  Av and Tv mode work the best over the full auto.

The grip feels sturdy and the camera body weighs just enough to carry for several hours without wrist fatigue.
Comments:
This camera is the "Jack of all trades and the master of none" in Canon's line-up of DSRLs.  It is a good camera but not perfect.

Reading the manual and mastering the controls is critical to taking good pictures as the full-auto mode disables too many useful features.

Title: Great service. Will come back anytime
Cons: None
Pros: I did not like the item. I returned and bought the different items. The services, the helpers, the operators and the processes are all excellent.

Title: Professional Quality for my Budget
Cons: White balance tends to get a little tricky. Shots in manual mode tend to look over-exposed when light meter indicates proper lighting.
Pros: The 40D has all the features you'd expect from a professional DSLR. Image quality is outstanding and it has a very nice large LCD for viewing shots. The camera is also very fast, shooting speed is impressive and is relatively quiet.
Comments: I purchased the 40D as an upgrade from the Canon XTi. After purchasing it, I know I made the right choice.

Title: Amazing
Cons: 1.6x crop frame, but hey, it was less than $2699.
Pros: Great pro camera. Practically everything about it is nice. The 3" screen is "gorgeous." 6.5FPS is nice and fast. The 40% magnified viewfinder is awesome. 10MP is great. 14bit raw is awesome.

Title: Canon 40D
Cons: This is the 4th 40D body I have owned over the last few months for various reasons. The latest and from what I am finding out, quite common is a serious problem with horizontal banding when shooting at high ISO's (Over 400) This is the 2nd body to exhibit this to varying degrees. A web search will explain more. Other than that it's the camera I reach for every time.
Pros: Well designed and manufactured. Easy to move through menu system. It's a Canon !
Comments:
Thanks to Newegg for great service and return policies! You guys ROCK!!

For some images sgot with the camera go to Strgazr27.Zenfolio.Com

ENJOY!

Title: Blurry images, focusing problems
Cons:
I bought  40d from from newegg. It shoots blurry images. I'm no amateur, worked as a professional photographer in a  studio (used 5D - for sport photography, 30D in studio, 20D, 350D, 450D). 
I thought it's just me (seeing things), then my friend (also a photographer) told me it too blurry... i made some test with high details (leaves, bar code). Blurry. It's not a movement problem at all. It is a focusing problem. Something with the sensor i guess.  
I quickly researched  online, several other people have the same issues. 
Going to send it back to newegg for exchange.
Pros: Wonderful (5 eggs) camera for the price if it would work.
Comments: Another friend of mine have 40D - SAME PROBLEM. She wants to send it back to Canon, since  she noticed it too late, after 30 days...

Title: Great Camera!
Cons: It's pretty big and heavy to lug around, especially with a zoom lens. I find it worth the tradeoff.
Pros: Simply great pictures! This camera offers plenty of flexibility to get the shot you want. It offers an auto mode that can give former point-and-shoot owners excellent photos while they learn how to use the "creative mode" settings. Other newer DSLR cameras have higher megapixel count, but the raw files will be proportionately larger, and the benefit very small unless you're making posters or doing some significant cropping. Plus the latest cameras in this class are all more expensive, so you need to make the judgement for yourself if the added features are worth all the extra cost. Newegg's price on this camera is very reasonable (low), and their service is excellent!
Comments: For new DSLR owners I recommend buying a separate guide book (e.g. David Busch has an excellent one out), since the manual covers the mechanics only.

Title: Definitely Wort It
Cons: Are you kidding?
Pros: Great build quality and picture quality, very fast, easily the best camera I've ever used.
Comments: Make sure you get a big CF card.  I got the 8GB Extreme III and it holds about 450-500 RAW files.  Get a card reader, too.  The USB on the camera is SLOW for some reason.

Title: DSLR goes Kaput
Cons: The camera died with an Error 99 after only a month and a half. I had to ship it back to the manufacturer and they don't do RMA. So I'll be missing my camera when I really need it. For something this expensive you'd think Canon would have better customer service. They are going to fix it under warranty, but now I have a really expensive refurbed camera.
Pros: Great Sensor, Good color, and the RAW format imports to everything I've used so far. Using the menu is a snap. If you shoot manual you'll be impressed at how easy it is to adjust on the fly. Really large view screen. Great Camera for the price.
Comments: I do want to say that Newegg has always had stellar customer service when I buy their products. This one is all on Canon.

Title: Great camera
Cons:
The highest ISO, 3200 is very noisy, almost non usable. Although, in order to use it, you have to dig in to the Cfn settings and enable it.
The screen is hard to see in very bright sun conditions.
As soon as I order it, Canon announced 50D, with more resolution, longer zoom kit lens, more ISO and better weather seal. I read the review (dpreview.com) and sample pictures look rather noisy, but judge for yourself. It's much pricier too.
Pros:
Big, heavy, feels professional. Great picture quality, lots of options. Menus and controls are well placed and easy to reach. 
I specially like the continuous shooting mode, up to 6 frames per second until the buffer is full, in my case is like 13 pictures shooting raw.
Comments:
I love it. The kit lens that comes with it is good for starting and all around shooting.
Worth the money. If you want anything better you would have to go to the canon 5d (but wait for the imminent upgrade) or to the new Nikon 90D that makes movies too.

Comments: Another friend of mine have 40D - SAME PROBLEM. She wants to send it back to Canon, since  she noticed it too late, after 30 days...

Title: Great Camera!
Cons: It's pretty big and heavy to lug around, especially with a zoom lens. I find it worth the tradeoff.
Pros: Simply great pictures! This camera offers plenty of flexibility to get the shot you want. It offers an auto mode that can give former point-and-shoot owners excellent photos while they learn how to use the "creative mode" settings. Other newer DSLR cameras have higher megapixel count, but the raw files will be proportionately larger, and the benefit very small unless you're making posters or doing some significant cropping. Plus the latest cameras in this class are all more expensive, so you need to make the judgement for yourself if the added features are worth all the extra cost. Newegg's price on this camera is very reasonable (low), and their service is excellent!
Comments: For new DSLR owners I recommend buying a separate guide book (e.g. David Busch has an excellent one out), since the manual covers the mechanics only.

Title: Definitely Wort It
Cons: Are you kidding?
Pros: Great build quality and picture quality, very fast, easily the best camera I've ever used.
Comments: Make sure you get a big CF card.  I got the 8GB Extreme III and it holds about 450-500 RAW files.  Get a card reader, too.  The USB on the camera is SLOW for some reason.

Title: DSLR goes Kaput
Cons: The camera died with an Error 99 after only a month and a half. I had to ship it back to the manufacturer and they don't do RMA. So I'll be missing my camera when I really need it. For something this expensive you'd think Canon would have better customer service. They are going to fix it under warranty, but now I have a really expensive refurbed camera.
Pros: Great Sensor, Good color, and the RAW format imports to everything I've used so far. Using the menu is a snap. If you shoot manual you'll be impressed at how easy it is to adjust on the fly. Really large view screen. Great Camera for the price.
Comments: I do want to say that Newegg has always had stellar customer service when I buy their products. This one is all on Canon.

Title: Great camera
Cons:
The highest ISO, 3200 is very noisy, almost non usable. Although, in order to use it, you have to dig in to the Cfn settings and enable it.
The screen is hard to see in very bright sun conditions.
As soon as I order it, Canon announced 50D, with more resolution, longer zoom kit lens, more ISO and better weather seal. I read the review (dpreview.com) and sample pictures look rather noisy, but judge for yourself. It's much pricier too.
Pros:
Big, heavy, feels professional. Great picture quality, lots of options. Menus and controls are well placed and easy to reach. 
I specially like the continuous shooting mode, up to 6 frames per second until the buffer is full, in my case is like 13 pictures shooting raw.
Comments:
I love it. The kit lens that comes with it is good for starting and all around shooting.
Worth the money. If you want anything better you would have to go to the canon 5d (but wait for the imminent upgrade) or to the new Nikon 90D that makes movies too.
